body: Crime has fallen across New York City for the 17th consecutive year, with subway crime down by more than 5 percent from last year and the number of recorded murders virtually certain to be the fewest in any single year since 1963, new Police Department statistics show. As of yesterday, there had been 537 killings in the city, according to the
title: CRIME NUMBERS KEEP DROPPING ACROSS THE CITY

body: BRAUN--Edith M. 102 years, on December 20, 2005. Lifelong resident of Greenpoint, Brooklyn and Enfield, New Hamsphire. Retired member of the UFT Association. Survived by a circle of cousins and friends. Funeral Friday, December 23rd from the Hugh A. Reid Funeral Home, 153 Greenpoint Ave., Brooklyn at 10am. Cremation at Fresh Pond Crematory.

body: JUST above the last G train stop in Brooklyn, in Greenpoint, there lies a working-class commercial strip lined with bodegas, electronics stores, and Polish and Mexican restaurants. title: STREET LEVEL -- Greenpoint; On a Creek With a Past, Waterfront Dreams

body: HOPE springs eternal. And so, James Vanderberg hoped. He hoped that his girlfriend would not leave him, and that therefore they would not have to relinquish their cozy one-bedroom on the Upper West Side. For months, her plans were unclear. She might leave for San Francisco, enticed by friends and the prospect of graduate school there. Or she might
title: THE HUNT; Hoping For the Best? Bummer

Court papers charged that a drug organization led by Rafael Perez has openly distributed
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Prosecutors Seek To Seize Hotel

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday vetoed the City Council's recent revocation of the landmark designation of the Austin, Nichols Warehouse, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''The mayor vetoed the Council's disapproval of the designation because it's a highly significant building designed by a historically significant architect,'' Mr. Bloomberg said
title: Mayor Uses Veto to Support Landmark Status

body: It is the only major subway line in New York that does not enter Manhattan. Its route is short: 16 stations at peak hours. Its trains, 4 cars instead of the usual 8 or 10, seem oddly truncated. Even the color of its route symbol, a sickly lime green, suggests unease. It's the G line, which rumbles between Queens and Brooklyn, and has never been
title: No Respect (and Soon, a Crew of One); Riders Fear That Even the G-Line Sprint Won't Be Enough

body: Bicyclists were elated when a major renovation of the Williamsburg Bridge finished two years ago included improvements to the pedestrian and bicycle path. But they were decidedly displeased at the addition of some two dozen steel plates that stuck up nearly two inches above the pathway. The raised plates covered joints in the bridge that allowed
title: Bridge Is So Smooth Now, Why Not Have Breakfast While You Ride?

body: In an unusual move, the City Council has voted to revoke the landmark status of the Austin, Nichols Warehouse in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a 1915 building designed by Cass Gilbert that won the designation in September. The Council's 43-to-6 vote on Wednesday, with one abstention, drew indignant protests from preservationists, who said
title: City Council Revokes Landmark Status for Brooklyn Warehouse, Upsetting Preservationists

title: Be Sure to Read the Handwriting on the Wall; Graffiti Artists Move Off the Street and to the Front of a Classroom

body: Eleven months after taking office in 2002, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled the most ambitious housing initiative undertaken by any mayor since Edward I. Koch -- a $3 billion, five-year plan to begin to tackle New York City's housing shortage by producing 65,000 apartments and homes for New Yorkers with low and moderate incomes. Several years
title: CAMPAIGNING FOR CITY HALL: THE ISSUES; Mayor Wins Wide Praise For Initiatives On Housing

body: For most of her life, Carol O'Neill has known the 55-acre oil spill lurking beneath the ground in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Greenpoint as a familiar smell, a sludgy tang redolent of gasoline and metal. ''When I was a kid, we knew that when you came back from Long Island for the summer, that's how you knew you were home,'' said Ms. O'Neill, 43,
title: An Old Oil Spill Divides a Brooklyn Neighborhood

body: GORDON--Robert Emmet, M.D. In Naples, FL, on October 27, 2005. He is survived by his wife, Shirley Graham Dillon, and seven children, John, James, Robert, Thomas, Ann O'Grady, Susan Palma and Ellen Smith, and four stepchildren, Thomas, Stephen and Michael Dillon and Marcia Reffel as well as 15 grandchildren, seven step-grandchildren and one
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GORDON, ROBERT EMMET, M.D.

body: IT seems counterintuitive, but the luxury real estate market is helping to build housing for low- and moderate-income people. Sometimes, the deals create what could be called sibling buildings -- for example, a 42-story luxury tower on West 43rd Street is linked to five renovated tenement buildings nine blocks to the north. It was a good deal for
title: The Benefits of the Boom

body: A lawsuit was filed yesterday on behalf of Greenpoint residents who claim that three major oil companies allowed millions of gallons of oil to seep under their homes and into nearby Newtown Creek. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, seeks damages related to the 1978 oil spill from ExxonMobil, ChevronTexaco and BP P.L.C. A
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Residents Claim Pollution Damage

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday outlined a plan to preserve or build an additional 100,000 homes for the poor and middle-income families, moving to grab the spotlight from his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, on a central issue in the mayoral race. The mayor's proposal would more than double the amount of housing envisioned in a city program he
title: Taking a Cue From Ferrer, Mayor Issues Housing Plan

title: In a Still-Growing City, Some Neighborhoods Say Slow Down

body: THERE are 18 precious days until the spelling bee final, and Josh Malamy will not waste a single one. He is boning up on Latin and Greek roots and studying the 794 pages of Scripps National Spelling Bee word lists on Spellingbee.com. Among the obscure words he recently memorized were ''chrysochlorous'' (a greenish-gold color) and ''choumoellier''
title: The Night Life of Bees

''We figured we would rent our whole lives,'' Ms. Quinci said. ''We didn't really
title: Cut-Rate Homes For Middle Class Are Catching On

body: Scale -- huge, imposing, daunting scale -- is what defines Noémie Lafrance's site-specific performance piece ''Agora,'' and what ultimately undercuts its impact. Still, this hourlong dance experiment and community fiesta generates considerable good will. So much so that it has already been extended to Oct. 1. The scale is imposed by the gigantic,
title: DANCE REVIEW; Going for a Waterless Dip With Roller Skaters, Bikers and Superstars

body: Dates are subject to change. September DANCENOW/NYC Egalitarian and fleet of foot, this 11-year-old festival features free or affordable dance programs by everyone from young choreographers to old pros like Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, Murray Spaulding and Sally Hess, in performing spaces in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem, the Cathedral Church of St. John
title: THE NEW SEASON DANCE; Shows to Fall For

body: A NEW dance season promises all the expected pleasures but some unexpected ones as well. The big companies and the big presenters clamor for our attention. But creeping among these mastodons are likable little furry creatures that don't always get noticed. There is something to be prized about the quirky, the odd, the improbable, even the
title: THE NEW SEASON DANCE; A Season's Quirks, Including Balanchine Meets Béjart

body: Alec Ounsworth has a sharp, nasal, quavery voice, and he exults in its every flaw as the singer and songwriter of Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, a New York City band that performed on Wednesday night at Warsaw in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. He reaches up to his whiniest high notes and sings long lines full of slides and cracks. Now and then, he breaks into
title: POP MUSIC REVIEW; Whiny Notes and Croaks, But Who's Complaining?

title: For Cleaner Courts in Brooklyn

body: WHEN Noémie Lafrance first saw the deserted 50,000-square-foot McCarren Park swimming pool, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 1996, it had been closed for 13 years. The concrete floor was cracked, littered with broken glass, graffiti and weeds. Seeing a public facility in such wretched disrepair, Ms. Lafrance, who lives nearby, had a strong emotional
title: DANCE; Everybody Into the Pool (and Dance)

Residents of Long Island City, Queens, are more used to this notion than some. On the waterfront, excavation in preparation for the construction of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; Along the Waterfront, The Mystery of the Cinnamon Buns

title: Businessman Battles the City For Power Plant

body: The Democratic mayoral candidates put Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's record on trial last night in the first official debate of the primary. But mixed in with the critiques were a string of overstatements, half-truths and factual errors. In particular, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, made several questionable assertions and inflated his own
title: THE RACE FOR MAYOR: FACTS; Taking Aim at the Incumbent, but Not Without Some Stretching of the Truth

body: Accusing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of failing to solve a city housing shortage, Fernando Ferrer said yesterday that he would preserve or build more than 100,000 low-cost homes if elected mayor by raising taxes on vacant land and forcing developers in certain areas to set aside housing for low-and middle-income New Yorkers. In making the $8.5
title: Ferrer and Bloomberg Trade Charges on How to Add Housing

body: It was little surprise yesterday when Anthony D. Weiner, the congressman from Brooklyn, declared himself a candidate for mayor. After all, formal announcement or not, Mr. Weiner has been actively campaigning around the city, lobbing criticism at his Democratic rivals and slogans at voters, for the better part of a year. But the announcement --
title: After Months of Practice, Weiner Enters Mayor's Race

body: LAND values along the still-fetid Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn have shot up because of plans for high-end housing on its banks, and now something similar seems to be happening at Newtown Creek, an oil-slicked industrial waterway that forms part of the border between Queens and Brooklyn. The potential for the affluent to join the effluent along the
title: BIG DEAL; The Affluent Meet the Effluent

body: Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, a Brooklyn Democrat who, by the way, doesn't drink, sponsored the bill, which is designed to help increase tourism by publicizing the more than 60 breweries in the state. It passed both houses in June and awaits action by the governor. Among the other New York City breweries listed by the Brewers Association, a
title: F. Y. I.

There are times when you have to reach for a tenuous metaphor to convey how homespun and straight from the heart a restaurant is; at other times, the scene sets
title: $25 AND UNDER; Fresh, Local and What She Feels Like Cooking

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Michael Pitt; Indie Nirvana

Officials of the Lower Manhattan
title: Demolition Company To Have Role Downtown

title: Spare Times

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg picked up three more union endorsements yesterday at a sometimes deafening campaign rally where he was cheered by a throng of construction workers. The endorsements came from the carpenters, painters and laborers unions, all of which generally lean Democratic and in 2001 supported Mr. Bloomberg's opponent, Mark Green.
title: More Unions Endorse Bloomberg

body: While public attention was focused on the city's ill-fated plan to build a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan over the past two years, the Bloomberg administration quietly labored over projects and development plans in corners of the city -- from Jamaica, Queens, to Staten Island -- that generated very few headlines. But the city has only so
title: Mayor Pursues Plans Outside Manhattan, and Even Critics Applaud

body: SOME summer days just aren't what you want them to be. The gray sky of morning never burns away to blue. The thunderstorms of night hang on as a steady drizzle. The high hopes of yesterday collide with the glum reality of today. So it was on the last Thursday in June, and there was not much that anybody at the Adventureland amusement park could do,
title: ONE SUMMER DAY; And Sometimes You Get Rained Out

body: New Yorkers can forget about the Olympic Equestrian Center on Staten Island and the Olympic Shooting Center at Pelham Bay Park and the Olympic Velodrome on the Harlem River in the Bronx, now that the city has lost its bid for the 2012 Olympic Games. The $144.6 million Aquatic Center and Volleyball Arena, in a new 35-acre park on the East River in
title: Without Games, the Sites Pass From Future to Never

body: He came here predicting outright victory, but after his hopes of winning the Olympics for New York collapsed Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged what many others in the city had been saying for several years: the bid had been a long shot. Garnering only a handful of votes and falling behind three other cities was an embarrassing end
title: Mayor Says Bid Was Worth a Shot, Even Long

body: In a legislative session dominated by talk of reform, lawmakers took one quiet step that has alarmed several New York City politicians: they created a second judge seat for the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn that many officials fear could be a vehicle for patronage. For the last few days elected officials and political candidates have condemned the
title: Bill to Alter Court Is Assailed in Brooklyn

body: Gail S. Leicht and Leonard A. Ruvolo are to be married this evening on the grounds of the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass. Martin S. Dorfman, the uncle of the bride, has received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate. The bride, 41, is the marketing and brand manager at Hercules Chemical Company, a maker of chemical plumbing
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Gail Leicht, Leonard Ruvolo

body: A certain postindustrial beauty still haunts the blocks along North Brooklyn's waterfront, where a Hopperesque panorama rendered in rust and brick stretches from Williamsburg to Greenpoint. Frozen in time and twisted in shape, some of these streetscapes once abuzz with factories are now better known as generic urban backdrops for cop shows. A
title: CITYWIDE; On the New Waterfront, a Place for the Old

body: Talking to the men who make up the alternative-comedy team Stella can, depending on your constitution, be both delightful and maddening. Rarely do the group's members -- Michael Ian Black, Michael Showalter and David Wain -- offer a straight answer. When asked why they're perpetually clad in suits, for example, Mr. Black, 33, said, ''They're
title: Guys Perpetually in Suits and Perpetually Silly? O.K.

body: To the Editor: ''The Great Awakening,'' by Suketu Mehta (June 19), is a beautiful article about life in Brooklyn. However, though there are those in Park Slope who may know more about gelato in Manhattan than about the roti in Brownsville, as Mr. Mehta stated, many of us not only explore much of Brooklyn, but also regularly enjoy the variety of
title: Savoring Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: I enjoyed your special Brooklyn section, but found several of the articles bizarre in the extreme. First there was ''Go East, Young Man,'' about a young white man who feels like a ''pioneer'' because he lives on Bogart Street, the street where Francie was born in ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.'' Bogart Street is said to be in a
title: Pioneers and Corpses

author: Suketu Mehta is the author of ''Maximum City: Bombay Lost and Found'' (Knopf).
body: AT a party on the Upper West Side in 2000, a distinguished American author, and longtime Manhattanite, asked where I lived. ''Brooklyn,'' I told him. He snorted. ''Poor people live in Brooklyn.'' Then he turned away to get some meat. Shortly after the party, to see if I could move from my rented apartment in Boerum Hill, I went looking to see what
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; The Great Awakening

body: SIXTY-FIRST Street in Bensonhurst isn't exactly at the heart of Brooklyn; it's more like where the appendix would be. It's not a fancy street, but it's very clean. The brick houses are either single or two-family. They have their own driveways and are only two stories high, so there's always a lot of sky. Kids who grew up on the block know how to
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; Because It's There

body: HERE'S an exercise. Google the words ''New Brooklyn'' and see how many hits you come up with. The answer: 15.7 million. Even allowing for the insane inclusiveness of an Internet search, that number reveals something profound about the frenzy -- cultural, gastronomic, architectural and otherwise -- that has seized what is affectionately known as
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/FACES OF A BOROUGH; Who Hurts?

body: THIS is how it happens. Priced out of Manhattan, you move from a shoebox in the East Village to a quiet, tree-lined neighborhood in Brooklyn, Carroll Gardens, say, or Park Slope. Or maybe you hole up in an underfurnished loft in Williamsburg. This is a temporary, even unexpected move. Somehow, in your imaginings of life in New York, the Jay
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Two Guys From the Hood

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

body: CALL it, fondly, home. Call it, fondly, 73$(0$) west longitude by 41$(0$) north latitude. A dot on a small map, nothing on a larger one. Go down any side street. Most of the streets are side streets. Let the mind and body wander. Down Norman Street, for example, named for a Scandinavian, although all the signs are Polish. Somebody yells,
title: VOICES; 'A Dot on a Small Map'

body: The authorities hauled a dozen men into a Queens courtroom yesterday and charged them with participating in a mob-run gambling and loan-sharking operation. They called the men chiefs, soldiers and associates in the Bonanno crime family, but to one defense lawyer, Mathew J. Mari, they looked more like ''the Geritol generation.'' The men were led
title: 12 Are Accused in Mob-Run Betting Scheme

body: City officials plan to build a two-way path for bicyclists and pedestrians in the middle of a heavily trafficked street just west of the Brooklyn Navy Yard where a cycling advocate was critically injured in March. The new bicycle path, announced on Tuesday by the City Department of Transportation, will be one-third of a mile long, only a tiny
title: Bike Lane Planned for Traffic-Choked Road in Brooklyn

body: LAST Sunday, the poet, archivist, erstwhile movie critic and avant-garde filmmaker Jonas Mekas departed Brooklyn for Venice, where he is representing Lithuania in the Biennale. Mr. Mekas left that East European country decades ago, when he was 22. His films are apparently not well known in his homeland, where he is known for his volumes of poetry.
title: FILM; The World Through Blood-Tinted Lenses

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's ambitious 20-year plan to ship the city's garbage away by barge was dealt a stinging setback yesterday in a City Council vote. It was the mayor's second major defeat this week on a signature initiative of his administration. The Council's vote blocking the mayor's plan will effectively stall it but does not kill it,
title: Mayor Blocked On Trash Plan In 2nd Setback

body: Russell Crowe, the actor with a combustible mix of temper, bad-boy image and a new film to promote, was arrested in a SoHo hotel yesterday morning after striking a desk clerk with a telephone because he could not get a call through to his wife in Australia, the police said. The attack occurred shortly after 4 a.m. in the lobby of the Mercer Hotel,
title: Russell Crowe Accused of Assault With Hotel Phone

body: The death of the West Side stadium underscores the excruciatingly difficult process that almost every ambitious civic project in New York City faces from inception, calling into question whether anyone can build big in New York anymore. The city once had a reputation for pulling off daunting municipal projects: creating a huge watershed upstate to
title: Another Big Idea Brought Down by Politics

body: AS hordes of publishers, booksellers and agents descend this weekend on the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for BookExpo America, the trade show featuring more than 2,000 exhibits, an enterprising group of 10 New York independent magazines will be pursuing a more homegrown effort, selling their wares around Brooklyn and Manhattan out of a
title: WORD FOR WORD; A Smattering of the City's Eight Million Stories

body: CHERYL ROGOWSKI planted her seeds of change in the black soil of Orange County, N.Y., in 1994. Her parents, first-generation Polish-Americans, built the W. Rogowski Farm, starting in the 1950's. Like most farmers in the area, they dedicated their land to the wholesale onion business. ''We sold 500 tons of onions every year,'' Ms. Rogowski said,
title: FARM TO MARKET; Women Find Their Place In the Field

body: A drunken driver slammed his van into a couple on a motorcycle yesterday morning in Brooklyn, dragging the motorcycle underneath it and fatally crushing its driver, the police said. The motorcycle passenger, the driver's girlfriend, was thrown free and was reported in serious but stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan, the police
title: Driver Charged With D.W.I. In Death of a Motorcyclist

body: I DON'T remember the first time I walked into Frank's Gourmet Deli on Smith Street, but it must have been a little more than a year ago, around the time I signed a lease a couple of blocks away in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Getting to know a new neighborhood is always a process of locating and evaluating the essentials -- grocery store, laundry,
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Comfort Food

body: At the start of a debate yesterday among the Democrats vying to be mayor of New York, only one, Representative Anthony D. Weiner, rose from his chair to answer questions addressed to him. He then continued to portray himself as an earnest outsider who would change the way government is run in the city. By the second round of questions, Gifford
title: Style Differences on Display as 4 Mayoral Rivals Debate

body: Traveling southwest on Driggs Avenue near the border of Greenpoint and Williamsburg in Brooklyn, cars pass a series of dusty fields on the right and a newly refurbished running track on the left. Traffic on nearby Lorimer Street passes the crumbling ruin of a long-dormant city pool. This is McCarren Park. It is the neighborhood's largest park, and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Alchemy Could Turn A Park's Roads Into Grass

body: The City Council overwhelmingly approved plans yesterday to rezone 175 waterfront blocks in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Williamsburg and Greenpoint, removing the last major hurdle to the city's most ambitious redevelopment effort in decades. The final plan -- the product of months of negotiations between the City Council and the Bloomberg
title: Council Approves Makeover of the Brooklyn Waterfront

body: New York City's mayoral candidates announced several endorsements yesterday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican, won the endorsement of the New York State Court Officers Association. Although the union has only 1,500 members in the city, the endorsement gave Mr. Bloomberg's campaign team the photo opportunity it was seeking as contract
title: Endorsements Announced by Mayoral Candidates

body: The campaigns of Fernando Ferrer, a Democratic candidate for mayor, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg clashed yesterday over Mr. Ferrer's claim that industrial jobs are being threatened by the rezoning of the North Brooklyn waterfront.The city's plans include taking over two parcels where a storage business and a fuel company now operate to create a
title: Ferrer and Mayor Clash on Brooklyn Rezoning

body: The helicopter pilot knows a New York no one else knows, the contours of the great green torch on Liberty Island, the towers of the Brooklyn Bridge as they appear to the suicidal, Yankee Stadium after the lights go out. Five hundred feet above the city streets, a pilot named Yossi Benbassat sped past such rare visions yesterday, past Central Park
title: Eyes in Sky Seek a Hidden, and Tainted, City; Environmentalists Track Pollutants in Waterways

body: Attractions Museums and Sites NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, Manhattan. Through July 30, ''Before Victoria: Extraordinary Women of the British Romantic Era,'' an exhibition of hundreds of rare manuscripts, letters, prints, memoirs and other items related to female iconoclasts who challenged the rules of British culture
title: Spare Times

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been pilloried by critics who say his relentless push for a Jets stadium on the West Side of Manhattan has distracted him from other important projects, like the troubled rebuilding efforts at the World Trade Center site. Political opponents have called him obsessed. Even some supporters have been perplexed by what
title: Fixated on Stadium? Mayor Says No, but His Letters Differ

body: City officials agreed yesterday to let developers turn the decaying north Brooklyn waterfront, with its relics of Brooklyn's industrial past, into a neighborhood of residential towers with a parklike esplanade along the East River. The plan, which rivals the ambition and scope of the creation of Battery Park City, would rezone a 175-block area of
title: City Backs Makeover for Decaying Brooklyn Waterfront

body: Verity Liljedahl's face fell yesterday when she spotted the drilling machines extracting soil samples from the earth underneath an abandoned loading dock on the waterfront in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. ''They're going to put buildings here,'' she said, her voice working against the loud, pneumatic cadence of the machines as two land surveyors measured
title: Greenpoint Residents See Change, but Not All Object

body: A second tree in Central Park has been found to be infested with larvae from the Asian long-horned beetle, although city and federal officials played down the potential threat to the park's 26,000 trees yesterday. The beetle larvae were discovered on Friday in an American elm near Fifth Avenue and 75th Street, four blocks north of the first tree
title: Long-Horned Beetle Found In a 2nd Central Park Tree

body: ONE Saturday last month, Leon Reid donned a hard hat and an orange worker's tunic and headed for a busy corner in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, where he bolted a bent telephone sign onto the top of a Verizon phone booth and screwed a crinkled one-way sign onto the top of a nearby pole. People drifted past, noticing nothing suspicious in their midst.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN AND BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Bending, Bolting And Evading The Police

body: To the Editor: Your April 17 editorial ''Get Brooklyn's Rezoning Right'' gets a great deal right by highlighting the need to make affordable housing ''a significant piece of the mix.'' But New York must go further. Rezoning Greenpoint and Williamsburg should also ensure that housing that is supposed to be affordable really is. This means putting a
title: Affordable Housing in Brooklyn

body: An editorial on this page last Sunday inaccurately described the parameters proposed for the residential redevelopment in Greenpoint-Williamsburg in Brooklyn. Developers could build up to 40 stories with affordable housing. Those who choose to build only luxury or market-rate units alone could build up to 35 stories.
title: Corrections

body: In New York, the eternal struggle to cope with the high cost of living has often meant a willingness to live with just about anyone, anyhow. Adults in their 30's routinely move back in with their parents. Young artists bunk with other young artists in $3,000-a-month apartments intended for two tenants, not six. Poor immigrants wedge themselves into
title: Need Turns Aging Strangers Into Roommates

body: From the East River's edge along the Greenpoint and Williamsburg communities of Brooklyn, the Manhattan skyline looks suitable for framing. The reverse view is not so photogenic. It is dotted with the ruins of mostly decayed industrial sites and overgrown lots. For three years, the Bloomberg administration has been working to transform the nearly
title: Get Brooklyn's Rezoning Right

body: THE day he missed the deadline for a National Endowment for the Arts grant, Joshua Mehigan decided he had had enough. An unsung, gap-toothed composer of lyrical, sharply observed verse, Mr. Mehigan had had a run of uncommonly bad luck, even by the standards of luckless New York poets. It was February of last year. Mr. Mehigan, then 34, had broken
title: CITYPEOPLE; Finding the Verse in Adversity

body: She wears hoop earrings and dark spindly eyeglass frames in the latest fashion. She carries a backpack and a digital camera. A young-looking 33 with sandy blond curls, she is a fixture on the streets of East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The hipsters never suspect a thing. She is Dana Ruppert, urban secret agent of sorts, on a mission to document every
title: Nancy Drew and the Hidden Loft; Tracking Illegal Apartments in Industrial Zones

body: HUGO MARTINEZ, a 54-year-old graffiti gallerist, has been living his work -- and living in his work -- since 1972, when as a philosophy major and student activist at City College he discovered Puerto Rican teenagers painting subway cars in railyards and helped organize them into a loose collective called United Graffiti Artists. Since then, he's
title: HABITATS/Somewhere in New York City; Using Graffiti as a Decorating Tool

body: BECAUSE Krista Whetstone lives on the Upper West Side she can make this vow, ''I will never go to the supermarket again.'' ''In the market where I grew up everybody knew the names of the checkout girls, and it was a social center for the whole town,'' she said of Guilford, Conn. ''Here people at the supermarket glare at my kids, and it's dirty and
title: Online Shopping Makes New York A Cardboard Jungle

body: CATERERS cook in obscure commercial spaces, down basement stairs, behind unmarked windows, often in offbeat neighborhoods, where rents are still affordable. Following a good food smell down a side street and into one of their clandestine kitchens, hoping to score something to eat, can lead to disappointment, unless you are looking for 200 chicken
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Caterer Morphs Into a Butterfly

body: One day in 1969, the pastor at St. Stanislaus Kostka Church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, made an announcement to his parishioners. A cardinal from Poland, the archbishop of Krakow, was coming to say Mass. Stella Gryziec, a beautician, brimmed with excitement. Krakow was not far from her hometown. ''So I strayed for a day from work,'' Ms. Gryziec
title: JOHN PAUL II: MEMORIES; A Brooklyn Retiree's Last Trip To See a Special Friend in Rome

body: City Council members threatened yesterday to scuttle an ambitious proposal to rezone an enormous swath of northwest Brooklyn unless Bloomberg administration officials rewrite the plan to include more low-cost housing. The administration's proposal for the 175 blocks in Greenpoint and Williamsburg would transform a crumbling, disused manufacturing
title: Council Threatens to Block Plan to Rezone in Brooklyn

body: Bradford N. Swett, a real estate developer active in the vigorous development of the Upper West Side of Manhattan in the 1980's and 90's, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69. The cause was glioblastoma, a type of brain cancer, his family said. Mr. Swett bought and refurbished residential and commercial buildings on the East and
title: Bradford N. Swett, 69, Developer Of Upper West Side Real Estate

body: Easter fell earlier than usual this year, but the chilly March weather did not keep crowds of worshipers from lining the sidewalk in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan yesterday. Hundreds wearing baseball caps, boaters and hats bedecked with lilies, irises and roses stood along 50th Street, waiting for the cathedral's doors to open for
title: On 5th Ave., a Pair of Lines: One for Worship, and One for the Parade

body: New York City's main building-service workers union is taking an unusual step to ensure that hundreds of janitors, doormen and security guards at apartment buildings planned for two Brooklyn neighborhoods are paid union-scale wages. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, persuaded allies in the City Council to introduce
title: Bill Demands Union Pay at Planned Brooklyn Developments

body: IN the last decade, Williamsburg in Brooklyn has been a first stop for young people new to the city, just out of college. As they have grown up, the neighborhood has too, evolving from dive bars and movie rental joints to chic sushi restaurants and designer furniture emporiums. Most of these Williamsburg devotees are now young professionals, often
title: Williamsburg Reinvented

body: ON a cold afternoon in February, Peter Cruz drove 40 minutes from Hempstead, Long Island, to the East Village, parked on Avenue B near East Seventh Street, and walked to the steps of St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church, which has presided over Tompkins Square Park since 1848. Mr. Cruz, 55, knew the stretch of sidewalk well. He grew up in Greenpoint,
title: When the Bell Tolls

body: THIS is a yarn about the old woman and the pool. Correction. Not old. Older. It's been more than 25 years since Ann L. Buttenwieser came up with the notion of giving the city a gift of a floating pool, and 15 years since she began working single-mindedly on realizing her dream. That's a mere New York minute when it comes to developing almost
title: Metro Matters; Maybe a Wish Holds Water, After All

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: ''RATS -- that's where I draw the line,'' Heather Duchowny said. She and her two roommates couldn't ignore the rustling in the walls or the droppings on the floor. They suspected mice. Their apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had already been visited with plagues: vermin, floods, swarming insects. But there it was, out in the open -- a rat,
title: THE HUNT; Too Many Creepy, Crawly Roommates

body: Most New York politicians have to wait until they reach that great city hall in the sky before something is named after them. But Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, is on a faster track. Yesterday, the Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation unveiled a new elevator at its Williamsburg office, which is known as Brooklyn A. The addition was
title: An Elevator Named Marty -- No, Really

body: The Newtown Creek Monitoring Committee knows all about sewage. But it also knows all about meetings. Created on Jan. 8, 1997, to oversee the lengthy rebuilding of the giant Newtown Creek sewage plant, the committee consists of 10 to 15 residents of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, who have met twice a month for the last eight years. And they will continue to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Meetings Seemingly as Endless As the Sludge Itself

body: The photographs in Brian McKee's ''Detritus'' series feel serendipitous, as if he scouted and shot buildings on leisurely trips to Asia and then sorted through the results, culling the best images. But the scouting happens before he ever leaves Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Mr. McKee, 27, typically does four to six months of Internet and library research
title: DIRECTIONS: PROCESS; Too, Too Perfect

body: THERE are couples with a lot in common, and then there is Deborah Fisher and Joel Murphy. Both are artists specializing in kinetic sculpture. They are nearly the same height, close to the same weight, and they both favor T-shirts, jeans, boots and short hair. They also share a strong distaste for traditional relationships. "We talk a lot about not
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; Deborah Fisher and Joel Murphy

body: Wanderers on Manhattan Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, inevitably confront an array of Polish merchants: bakeries selling plump Polish pastries and diners serving steaming plates of pirogi. No one is questioning the neighborhood's position as the center of New York's Polish community, a distinction it has had since the postwar years. Not yet. But
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RIDGEWOOD; A Once-German Neighborhood Is Looking More Like Little Poland

body: STEVEN HOLL'S latest building, a water filtration plant shaped like a pipe, covered in stainless steel shingles and set in a field on the outskirts of New Haven, is hard to miss -- as long as you know where to look. Concerned that it could attract terrorists, the South Central Connecticut Regional Water Authority is trying to keep the plant's
title: ARCHITECTURE; In My Backyard, Please: The Infrastructure Beautiful Movement

body: TIEN MAO, 26, grew up in Manhattan and lives in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. In short, New York is his home -- his first and only home. Which may explain the distaste that Mr. Mao feels for ''The World's Second Home,'' the phrase that could wind up as the city's slogan, if U.S. Patent No. 78484751 is approved and the political stars align. ''Could this
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Who You Callin' Second?

body: Detectives believe that whoever dismembered the body of a 19-year-old Brooklyn man whose limbs and torso were found in a subway tunnel and at a recycling plant cut him apart with precision and has some knowledge of anatomy, the police said yesterday. The police also disclosed that a third set of remains -- another piece of what they believe was the
title: Body Was Cut Up Expertly, Police Say

body: A badly decomposed partial human torso found yesterday in a Brooklyn recycling plant that handles trash from subways may be from the same man whose limbs were found last week in a subway tunnel three miles away, the police said. The lower torso, with an upper thigh, was found about 10 a.m. by a worker at the Rapid Processing recycling plant at 860
title: Worker Finds a Partial Torso In a Brooklyn Recycling Plant

body: The first formal memorial at ground zero -- a stainless-steel reliquary honoring those who died in the Feb. 26, 1993, bombing and those who brought the World Trade Center back to life -- will be dedicated next week on the 12th anniversary of the attack. After a service at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church nearby and a moment of silence at the site
title: At 9/11 Site, First Memorial Is for 2/26/93

body: A new study by researchers at New York University recommends that the city require developers to include lower-cost apartments in large apartment buildings in fast-growing neighborhoods. Although the Bloomberg administration and the real estate industry have said such actions should be voluntary, the study says that under the right conditions it
title: Study Urges City to Require Building of Low-Cost Housing

body: Thaddeus Kosciuszko, a native Pole who came to America in 1776, befriended Thomas Jefferson and fought for the colonies in the Revolutionary War, distinguished himself in his adopted homeland as an engineer. Nevertheless, for most New York City commuters and drive-time radio listeners, Kosciuszko's name signals one thing: gridlock. His namesake,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEWTOWN CREEK; Plans and Wary Neighbors For an Icon of Gridlock

body: The board of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary has voted not to extend the contract of the Rev. Dr. Norman J. Kansfield, the school's president. The board acted in part because Dr. Kansfield officiated at the same-sex marriage of his daughter, a seminary official said. In a separate action, a spokesman for the national headquarters of the
title: Seminary Votes Out Leader Over Daughter's Gay Wedding

body: Seven years ago, Automotive High School in Brooklyn was producing such poor writers that the state considered shutting it down. Even the automotive program, once the soul of the school, was slashed over the years to bolster lagging academics. But this year, there are two fledgling advanced placement courses. The National Honor Society banner,
title: Vocational School Sets Sights On Mechanics Who Can Write

Bloomberg's proposal to eliminate smoking from all indoor public places, few opponents were more fiercely outspoken than James McBratney, president of the Staten Island Restaurant and Tavern Association. He frequently ripped Mr. Bloomberg as a billionaire dictator with a
title: As Air Clears, Even Smokers Are Converted

body: Pedestrians and cyclists, limited only by their own hamstrings and quadriceps, could one day travel 22 miles along a waterfront greenway from North Brooklyn to Coney Island, under a plan to be unveiled today. The vision of strolling or whizzing past bustling parks and quaint row houses or taking in panoramic views of the Manhattan skyline,
title: Long, Green Pathway Planned Along Brooklyn Waterfront

body: A 19-year-old parolee who was prowling with childhood friends on the Lower East Side early on Thursday morning has been charged with murdering a young actress who talked back to them as they robbed her companions, the police said yesterday. The police said that the arrest of the man, Rudy Fleming, came after detectives received tips from people who
title: Parolee, 19, Is Held in Death Of Actress During Robbery

body: Nicole duFresne, an actress and playwright with a boisterous laugh and a head full of ideas, had packed a lot into 28 years, including four cities, dozens of plays, theater companies, classes and political protests. She had also been assaulted by a rapist, and she carried that mix of temperament and experience into her last minutes early Thursday
title: An Actress Who Strode Boldly Through Life, Right Up to the End

body: A 28-year-old actress and playwright was shot to death on the Lower East Side early yesterday after she and her companions were surprised by two young men trying to rob them, the police and her fiancé said. The actress, Nicole duFresne of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was shot once in the chest after her fiancé was pistol-whipped and one of the men
title: Actress Killed in Lower East Side Robbery

body: Much has been said in the last few days about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's plan to introduce fully computerized subway service, starting with the L line in July. But unknown to many riders, a significant element of the plan -- the conductorless train -- is not new. In 1996, the authority quietly began using only a motorman, also
title: Riders Skeptical of Plan for Conductorless Trains

body: WHEN Emily Haddad moved to New York shortly after finishing college in 2001, she didn't know much about the city, but being gay, she knew she wanted to live in a gay-friendly community. Her neighborhood of choice? Park Slope. ''It seemed like lesbian central in New York,'' said Ms. Haddad, 24, whose unaccented speech belies her North Carolina
title: URBAN TACTICS; Replanting The Rainbow Flag

body: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, said yesterday that he opposed an enormous rezoning proposal for Greenpoint and Williamsburg because it did not guarantee enough inexpensive housing, open space or economic stability for people already living in the area. Although the City Planning Commission and the City Council have the ultimate
title: Brooklyn Rezoning Plan Assailed

body: Steven Parrino, an artist and musician who imbued abstract work in several mediums with a relentless if oddly energetic punk nihilism, died early Saturday morning in a traffic accident near his home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. He was 46. Mr. Parrino was returning from a New Year's Eve party in Williamsburg when he apparently lost control of his
title: Steven Parrino, 46, an Artist And Musician in a Punk Mode
